item.title: Soldering
item.description: Soldering Soldering is the process of connecting a component to a PCB by melting solder between the surfaces. Traditionally, soldering is done using a soldering iron - essentially a very hot stick of metal that you gently touch to heat the circuit board, solder, and component together.

item.title: Ergonomic Keyboards
item.description: Ergonomic Keyboards An ergonomic keyboard is a tool for inputting symbols to a computer in a way that doesn’t compromise on the user’s comfort. Typical features that might make a keyboard more ergonomic that the traditional counterpart are a split design, ortholinear or columnar staggered keys, or non-traditional angles.

item.title: Neutrons
item.description: Neutrons Topic: Atoms Neutrons are neutrally charged subatomic particles found inside the Nucleus of an atom. References.

item.title: Atoms
item.description: Atoms Atoms are the fundamental particle of matter, once believed to be the smallest unit of matter. Each atom consists of a Nucleus holding Protons and Neutrons, and a cloud of Electrons surrounding it.

item.title: Antiparticles
item.description: For every type of particle there is an antiparticle, also known as antimatter. The theory of antiparticles was first proposed by Paul Dirac in 1928. It has been confirmed by discovery when Don Anderson found the positively charged electron, positron, in 1932.

item.title: Alpha Radiation
item.description: Alpha Radiation Alpha radiation is made up of a stream of alpha particles: two Protons and two Neutrons. This is a helium nuclei with no electrons. They have a positive charge.

item.title: Absolute Zero
item.description: Absolute Zero There is no upper limit to temperature, in principle. Eventually things will become plasma, but they can keep heating up. On the other side of the scale, there is a lower limit to temperature.

item.title: Genes
item.description: Genes Topic: Genetics Genes are small segments of the giant DNA molecules. They can be thought of as forming the words to the chapters that are chromosomes, themselves part of the book that details your genetic master code.

item.title: Chromosome
item.description: Chromosome Topic: Genetics A chromosome is a coiled chain of the molecule DNA that indicate your Genes. A human has 46 chromosomes. The nucleus is bigger than the chromosome is bigger than the ==gene==.

item.title: Math Notation
item.description: \mathbb{R}^{n} means the n-dimensional real coordinate space. It represents all possible real valued n-tuples. \in means that something is an element or member of something else, e.g: \vec{x}=\begin{bmatrix} 0 \\ 0 \\ 0 \end{bmatrix} \text{, }\vec{x}\in \mathbb{R}^3.
